channel.name: How  does `getActions` with endHash works in a reducer?

messages.content:
After discussing with @garethtdavies, i'm trying to wrap my head around understanding how does sequence_state & its precondition work together with getAction's endHash.

I though i'd be able to specify an endHash, in case i only want to process the following 5 actions, not all '100' actions waiting to be processed. Is this possible? I was able to replicate this by calling getActions outside of the circuit and finding the corresponding hash i want to 'process to', so i'd look for the 5th action and take the hash from its object. This worked on LocalBlockchain.

Is there also a limit to how many actions can be dispatched and ready to be processed? Because the reducer has a limit for how many actions it can process at once, and thats part of the circuit.. if there is more actions waiting to get processed what does happen then? In my experience the reducer wont work, since there is more actions as there is in the defined limit (maxTransactionsWithActions).
also this partial action processing worked with LocalBlockchain ^^, i’d expect it works also on berkley since the reducer getAction arguments api is probably provided for a reason

In my experience (and what led to this discussion) is that you have to process all pending actions for the transaction to be accepted on Berkeley. From the RFC likely this isn't how it is intended to work, as you should be able to specify any of the last 5 sequence states as a precondition stored on the account.
This will be much easier to test once we have the archive node API 😅
i vote we make the LocalBlockchain an actual wasm node after openmina’s node becomes fully available?

potential inconsistencies between Local/Berkley/Mainnet could become a big dealbreaker if apps are developed against local and then dont work at all on berkley due to gaps in design due to feature asymmetry
Great questions and ideas @maht0rz. Thank you for being so engaged.
also judging by looking at this API, im not sure if this endHash behavior is even intended https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/pull/12696/files

embeds.title: [RFC] - Add Archive Node API RFC by MartinMinkov · Pull Request #12...
embeds.description:
Description
This PR describes a GraphQL server that exposes events/actions from an Archive Node.

messages.content: @Deleted User I don't see 'endHash' in the file and I'm not quite sure what you're asking? If you still need help I can try to track down @o1martin who wrote the service.

It's documented here https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/advanced-snarkyjs/actions-and-reducer#actions-for-concurrent-state-updates and `this.reducer.getActions({ fromActionsHash?: Field, endActionsHash?: Field }): A[][];`. It seems given the API this isn't possible to specify the `endActionsHash` so what is the purpose of `endActionsHash`. Is it the case that all pending actions have to be processed or can they be reduced in chunks and what determines where you can split them as there is a precondition added to the transaction to the current(?) sequence state.

embeds.title: Actions & Reducer | Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Please note that zkApp programmability is not yet available on Mina Mainnet, but zkApps can now be deployed to Berkeley Testnet.

messages.content: Yes that’s correct, you can’t reduce actions in chunks - you have to process either all pending actions or non, in chunks won’t work since the protocol expects a different commitment. Arguably there might be a handful of edge cases where you might want to fetch a range of actions anyway,  but you won’t be able to process them
So, probably something we should remove
thanks for the explanation cc @garethtdavies you were right
@Florian how does this work if my reducer has maxTransactionsWithActions: 32, and there are 33+ pending actions to process?
Without a workaround, you won’t be able to reduce them since the commitment will not match

Another Q: what happens when i start producing my rollup block for a set of fetched actions, and i’d produce a resulting sequenxe state since i processed all known actions at the time. And a new action gets dispatched while my rollup is being reduced, therefore my rollup wont pass sequenxe state precondition?
i’m trying to confirm my understanding of how it operates, before i try to devise a solution/workaround (i have some in mind)
If the action makes it through before your rollup, the rollup will fail. You can set preconditions tho

A counter that you increment with each dispatch and then you check 

actionsCounter.assertLessThan(32)
yep thanks makes sense!
Each account maintains 5 sequence states on the chain, I think there will be no problem as long as your accumulated actions match one of the 5.
@Comdex based on what @Florian has said, there should be only 1 sequence state to match with using a precondition. But based on the original RFC it should be possible (i think)
Yes, my conclusions come from the original RFC 😅
yeah thats why i raised the original Q, our experiences together with gareth were inconclusive with RFC vs Snarky impl vs Berkley vs LocalBlockchain
Yeah, I'd like to understand why there are 5 sequence states (soon to be action states) stored on the account if only the latest is a valid precondition.

In SnarkyJS, when reducing a list of pending actions, we set the precondition so that it matches the on-chain sequence state (which is one field) <https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/main/src/lib/zkapp.ts#L1316>
But you are right, on the protocol that state consists actually of 5 fields (I would assume those are the last 5 states, with index 0 being the current one)
Just wondering is this is a old remnant of the RFC, as mentioned above it was planned you could match any of the 5 states. Is there any current use/need to store 5?
i think the best would be if the precondition could match any of the existing actions that can be processed

Hey @garethtdavies @maht0rz @Comdex @Florian, what I wrote in the RFC is still true:
The 5 sequence states on every account are the states after the last 5 blocks which have any actions for this account. The precondition has to match any of the 5.
This means there is a very limited possibility of reducing up to an earlier point in the history, but that's not what the 5 states are intended for (it's too limited to be useful for that).
The 5 states are intended for what Matej describes: the situation where you start creating a proof with sequence state from the last block, and while you create that proof, a new block with new actions arrives. The fact that we can match any of 5 states means that in this case, our precondition will still be valid
And yeah - endActionsHash is not very useful, in hindsight 😅
That's not possible on Mina, since we don't store transaction history 😛
yes but you could store more than 5 for the precondition, lets say 50, and anything older than 50 (actions) then basically becomes unusable as the precondition
problem is that without endHash using a reducer sets you up for failure / inability to produce a rollup block, if you have a lot of actions to process

the only sensible way to use reducers today is to limit dispatch and keep track of # of dispatched actions on chain. producing a rollup block then resets the action counter and allows then for further dispatching again
Yeah we should create a ZkProgram which can reduce arbitrary numbers of actions with recursion, that would solve it
